Akira Drake RodriguezKenton CardMargit MayerHugo SarmientoABSTRACT

Climate adaptation in Latin American cities involves navigating highly contested social and cultural terrains. In cities with black and indigenous communities they are confronted with challenges such as histories of racial exclusion and informal, self-built housing in high-risk areas. This study examines Project Plan Jarillón, a flood protection infrastructure project in Santiago de Cali which involves Latin America’s largest relocation project. Cali, home to a large Afro-Colombian population, is also one of Colombia’s fastest growing cities and the second largest reciever of internally displaced persons (IDPs) in the country. The study, based on 5 years of fieldwork including site visits and interviews, found the city’s failure to account for the segregation of black residents in high-risk areas has led to resistance, conflict and delays in the completion of the project. However, by forming an insurgent planning practice which draws from local culture and traditions of resistance, Afro-Colombian communities re-centered public debate on demands for racial and cultural recognition, and the right to decent housing. This insurgent planning is creating more democratic forms and approaches to climate adaptation in Cali at a pivotal moment in Colombia’s history as it negotiates a post-conflict process and positions itself as a global advocate for climate justice.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

Latin American cities experiment with climate adaptation strategies in highly unequal and contested social terrains. As in urban geographies across the global south, more generally, this contestation is reflected in disputes over land, exclusion from formal housing markets and racial segregation in high-risk areas (Alvarez and Cardenas, 2019; Loughran and Elliot, 2022; Dodman et al., 2019). Moreover, critical perspectives on climate adaptation point to an emerging climate urbanism in which adaptation strategies including the construction of protective infrastructure, such as levees and seawalls, and the relocation of residents away from risk areas, carry with them the potential for displacement and the reinforcing of existing spatial inequality (Anguelovski et al., 2016; Castán Broto et al., 2020). While this scholarship, based in political economy, provides a critical framework for analyzing the results of these strategies, it has yet to fully examine the role historically oppressed communities can play in shaping urban climate adaptation through insurgent planning practices which draw on unique cultural settings and traditions of resistance. At stake in these insurgent practices are new approaches to climate adaptation that address underlying social and economic injustices and promote more democratic forms of climate governance.

In a case study the research presented here examines the insurgent planning practices of Afro-Colombian communities in Santiago de Cali. It focuses on community resistance to Project Plan Jarillón, a flood infrastructure project which involves the large-scale relocation of communities that inhabit the city’s levees. Created in response to the increasing frequency of torrential rain and chronic flooding in Cali, Plan Jarillón has generated a contentious debate, and at times violent conflict, over forced evictions and the city’s approach to climate adaptation. These relocations, the largest of their kind in Latin America, involve approximately forty thousand residents, and impact nearly one million residents in the surrounding communities.1 They take place at a pivotal moment in the Colombia’s history as it both negotiates the post-conflict transition and positions itself as a global advocate for climate justice.

The study operationalizes Miraftab’s (2009) definition of insurgent planning as counter-hegemonic and transgressive acts of resistance which challenge dominant neoliberal forms of planning in the context of urban climate adaptation. An emphasis is placed on the unique cultural origins and dimensions of these insurgent planning practices. Specifically, it views them through a politics of place frame, drawing on spatial theories and analytics found in the settler colonial and black geographies literature. The study is guided by the following set of questions. What are the insurgent planning practices of Afro-Colombian communities in response to Project Plan Jarillón? And, how are they shaping climate adaptation in Cali?

The study finds that by forming an insurgent planning practice, informed by local culture, historic traditions of resistance and powerful counter-narratives, black communities in Cali have successfully re-centered public debate on demands for racial and cultural recognition. This recognition has won them the ability to make legal claims on collective land rights, territorial sovereignty and the right to decent housing. In turn, Plan Jarillón has changed its relocation strategy to prevent further displacement and include a wider range of housing alternatives, to engage communities in a more participatory planning process and to create new environmental stewardship programs. In this way, these communities are transforming the city’s existing housing strategy and governance structures for climate adaptation.

Literature review

To date, the critical scholarship on urban climate adaptation has not fully engaged the politics of place literature, specifically as it relates to theorizing the racial and cultural dimensions of development. The black geographies and settler colonial literature can be especially useful in offering analytical frames for understanding the spatial implications of urban climate adaptation in geographies marked by histories of racism and colonialism (McKittrick and Woods, 2007; Porter and Yiftachel, 2017). It reminds us that embedded in the dominant paradigms of urban planning, including climate adaptation, are particular socially and culturally constructed views of development. Therefore, at stake in adaptation planning is not just the mitigation of climate risk but also the erasure of local cultural practices and histories, and along with them alternative social environmental practices in response to the climate crisis.

Drawing on political economy, critical urban scholars point to an emerging “climate urbanism,” that is, a development paradigm in which climate adaptation predominantly relies on exclusionary forms of governance and market-based planning strategies (Long and Rice, 2021). This climate urbanism features top down, technocratic solutions which emphasize engineering, physical infrastructure interventions and land use planning tools such as risk zoning. For example, these may include the construction of protective infrastructure such as levees and seawalls, and the relocation of residents away from risk areas carry through managed retreat interventions. However, these interventions are less concerned with changing the underlying patterns of social and economic inequality which produces uneven distributions of risk. (Long et al., 2020; Ziervogel, 2021) In fact, they may create new governance structures and institutional arrangements which reinforce existing power asymmetries and spatial inequality (Anguelovski et al., 2016; Castán Broto et al., 2020; Pelling 2011). Moreover, as a development discourse, it is increasingly circulated on a global scale by national and international development agencies, including banks which finance development and local actors such as municipal governments which according to Leitner et al. (2018) constitutes a “resilience industrial complex” (Castán Broto et al., 2020; Leitner et al., 2018). Bulkeley (2015) adds these interventions can be understood as biopolitics—political performances in which existing urban regimes deploy a set of climate discourses to normalize and stabilize new forms of hegemony. Therefore, they can result in development pathways which lead to displacement through what Anguelovski et al. (2016) call “acts of commission and acts of omission.”

While these views on urban climate adaptation, rooted in political economy, establish much needed critical perspectives, the study of adaptation in ethnically and culturally diverse urban landscapes, such as those found in in Latin American cities, demands a deeper examination of the racial and cultural factors which uniquely condition the urbanization process. Specifically, it must pay closer attention to how racial identities and culture influence housing market outcomes and land tenure patterns which underly the spatial distribution of climate risk. The politics of place literature has much to offer in this regard. The black geographies literature for example provides analytical frames which center the discursive and spatial logics of racial exclusion found in segregated environments. For example, it identifies discursive techniques such as the othering and stigmatizing of racially oppressed communities in addition to bringing into view the role of land and housing markets as the mechanisms by which these spatial arrangements are produced (Allen et al., 2019; McKittrick and Woods, 2007). Relatedly, the settler colonial literature provides insight on the histories of dispossession which mediate the spatial power relationships between social elites and communities in the urban periphery (Porter and Yiftachel, 2017; Porter et al., 2020a). This literature therefore offers a reframing that is crucial for understanding climate risk in Latin American cities characterized by the presence of historically oppressed black and indigenous communities and their segregation in peripheral informal settlements.

These frames also surface local traditions of resistance and cultural practice which can shape urban planning and produce more just forms of climate adaptation. The literature on climate activism reveals that dominant forms of climate urbanism are very much contested. The communities subjected to these experiments in adaptation planning have never been passive actors (Johnson et al., 2022; Ziergovel, 2021). The large scale and public nature of investments required to respond to the climate crisis, creates opportunities for new political actors to emerge and propose alternative transformative adaptation strategies. These can be found in grassroots efforts and bottom-up approaches to climate adaptation (Fox et al., 2021). For instance, this literature shows that by creating “spaces of resistance” and “governance through activism” indigenous communities bring into view new and alternative forms of adaptation (Borie et al., 2019). That is, this emerging climate activism forces recognition of indigenous culture and narratives as a different system of knowledge which has much to offer in the creation of more open and democratic forms of climate adaptation (Johnson et al., 2022; Ziergovel, 2021).

In Latin American cities, in particular, oppressed, black and indigenous communities historically have responded to social and spatial exclusion by forming political traditions of resistance and strategic counter-planning (Bledsoe 2017). One of the more visible, and common, examples of this resistance is the contestation of space through self-built housing practices and the construction of informally developed settlements. These are dynamic traditions which often draw on cultural resources to form counter-narratives and have been able to transform policy as it relates to housing, infrastructure, and governance structures more broadly (Eckstein, 2001; Escobar, 1992). Without recognizing this it is difficult to understand the salience of these insurgent practices and their transformative potential in urban climate adaptation.

Finally, this reframing broadens how reparative forms of climate justice might be conceived in cities of the global south. By centering land dispossession and racial exclusion in the housing market in the production of climate risk, these perspectives shift the focus of climate policy from technocratic planning interventions to more democratic governance in adaptation planning, access to decent housing and cultural recognition. Thus, a deeper and more sustained engagement with the politics of place enables an understanding of the social and cultural implications of insurgent practices for climate policy. It brings into view alternative spatial logics, based on anti-racist and anti-colonial resistance, which may point to new pathways for climate adaptation. Recalling Pelling’s (2011) resilience-transition-transformation framework, in this sense, reparations may be the social and political mechanism which enables a climate adaptation which goes beyond resilience (stability) and transition (incremental social change and the exercising of existing rights) to transformation (new rights claims and changes in political regimes).

Methods and data collection

The primary method used in this study is a comparison of insurgent planning practices in three Afro-Colombian communities in Cali. These communities were selected based on their inclusion in Plan Jarillón’s resettlement plans, their representation by community councils identifying as ancestral black communities in Colombia, and their active engagement in organizing anti-displacement efforts. These communities are Playa Renaciente, Brisas del Cauca and La Palma, all located in the informal settlements found on the levee. The analytical strategy involved comparing the insurgent practices of these communities and identifying common strategies they used to resist displacement, engage the city and to advocate for change in the city’s resettlement plans over a 5-year period (2017–2022).

To observe their impact on the city’s climate policy and planning strategy, in-depth interviews of project directors and city agencies, informal interviews at public hearings, and document analysis were conducted during the study period. This period also captures a change in city government and Plan Jarillón’s leadership, following municipal elections, which allowed for an observation of the impact insurgent planning had on the city’s policy agenda.

Data was collected through site visits, participant observation and interviews in Cali and Bogota between 2017 and 2022. The project’s planned relocation phase and resistance to forced evictions reached their peak during this period. Interviews (n = 24) consisted of community council leaders in all three communities, residents on the levee and resettled residents in two social housing projects, Llano Verde and Potrero Grande. Expert interviews (n = 12) included the directors of the Plan Jarillón project in Bogota and in Cali including the city’s secretaries of risk management and social housing, in addition to the project’s field teams. Informal interviews were also conducted at public hearings held by the city. Finally, site visits (n = 8) included accompanying Plan Jarillón’s engineers on their inspection of the levee and flood protection system.

Secondary data, such as geospatial housing and demographic census data was obtained from the city’s public database Infraestructura de Datos Especiales (IDESC) and supplemented with data from Universidad del Valle’s Centro de Investigaciones Territorio, Construcción y Espacio (CITCE).

Fieldwork was supported by faculty at the Pontificia Universidad Javeriana (PUJ) in Bogota and at its campus in Cali, and the Asociación Mejorando Vidas (ASOMEVID), a community-based non-profit in the Aguablanca district. As a visiting researcher at PUJ, my institutional affiliation enabled access to local city and community institutions in addition to secondary data sources. I am Latin American and a native Spanish speaker, allowing me to conduct interviews in the local language. Interviews were later translated to English for coding and analysis.

FindingsClimate adaptation in Santiago de Cali

Climate adaptation in Cali is viewed as a strategic investment in Colombia’s long-term economic development. The largest city in Colombia’s Pacific Coast region, and one of the fastest growing economies in the country, Cali occupies a pivotal node in transportation networks near one of the country’s most important connections to global trade, the Buenaventura Port, and vital manufacturing and agricultural centers in the Cauca Valley. It is also the second largest receiver of ‘desplazados” or internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Colombia, which along with economic migrants from coastal communities, drives rapid population growth.2 However, the city is vulnerable to flooding given its low-lying position and proximity to the Cauca River.

In 2012 Colombia’s Fondo Adaptación, a public investment fund, invested over a hundred million US dollars to upgrade the city’s levee and flood infrastructure (See Table 1). Fondo Adaptación was created in 2010 in response to the 2010-2011 winter storms which caused widespread damage to housing and transportation infrastructure throughout Colombia, and placed climate adaptation on the national agenda.1 Originally conceived as a temporary agency to assist in the country’s recovery efforts, in 2015 the fund was permanently assigned to Colombia’s Secretary of the Treasury. It closely coordinates its work with Colombia’s disaster risk management agency (UNGRD). As such, its primary objective is to mitigate the financial risk posed by climate disasters through investments in housing and regional infrastructure projects.Table 1.Distribution of Plan Jarillón Costs in USD.Source: Contraloria General de Santiago de Cali 2017.

Cali sought a partnership with Fondo Adaptación, following the 2010-2011 winter storms which resulted in catastrophic flooding across the city’s eastern periphery. During this event, the Cauca River’s increased water flows threatened a full breach of the Cali’s levee and flood control system.3 Launched in 2013, Project Plan Jarillón aims to reinforce the levee and to relocate and resettle communities occupying it. Officially Plan Jarillón Cali operates under the direction of the city’s Secretary of Risk Management of Emergencies and Disasters, however in practice it operates autonomously and communicates directly with Fondo’s headquarters in Bogota to formulate its financing strategy.

In the same year, the city commissioned hydrological engineering consultants from Holland, Royal HaskoningDHV, to perform flood simulations and conduct a risk assessment of the levee system. The assessment found in a worst-case scenario, (see Figure 1), nearly nine hundred thousand residents could be affected by flooding. Seventy-five percent of the city could lose access to potable water for up to 4 months due to incapacitated water treatment plants currently found in the floodplain, and the city would incur economic damages of approximately four billion USD.4 Based on this analysis, the study identified six critical points along the levee in need of major structural reinforcements.Figure 1.Catastrophic flooding simulation in Cali. Source: IDESC, City of Santiago De Cali.

The costliest and most complex component of the project would involve the relocation and resettlement of the communities occupying the levee. A survey of the levee identified close to 8770 households in these communities.5 A project manager at Fondo Adaptación explained, “Surely if the levee fails, the first affected will not be those on the levee but those next to it below the water level...This is not just a social risk but a huge financial risk.”

Challenges to the city’s relocation strategy

Unlike Bogota and Medellin, Cali lacks a resettlement policy, the institutional capacity and the financial instruments needed to relocate communities from the city’s high-risk areas. Plan Jarillón had to improvise new housing and compensation strategies including a combination of social housing subsidies and home buyouts. Complicated by high levels of informality at project sites, and the difficulty in verifying property lines and household members, this approach resulted in an uneven relocation process.

City officials describe the levee, and its communities, as an urban frontier in which residents live beyond the reach of state institutions engaging in a range of unsanctioned commercial and illicit activities. They refer to this part of the city has having been settled through waves of land “invasions.” Relocations, and forced evictions, when necessary, therefore, represent a restitution of public land. However, residents counter that they are being dispossessed by Plan Jarillón. Many of them identify as desplazados, or “victims of the [civil] conflict,” and as Afro-Colombian. Both social categories possess special legal protections according to the 1991 Colombian Constitution negotiated in the post-conflict process and the more recent 2011 Law of Victims and Land Restitution. These protections include the right to decent housing and compel public institutions to guarantee them in planning interventions such as Plan Jarillon.6

Located in the city’s eastern periphery the levee area largely developed outside of formal urban planning. At the time of its completion in the 1950s the levee, originally built by the Corporación Autónoma Regional del Valle del Cauca (CVC), a public entity modeled after the Tennessee River Valley Authority, was bordered by a rural agricultural zone far from the city’s urban core. Beginning in the 1990s, however, communities displaced by violence and economic crisis began to occupy the area culminating in the large consolidated informal settlements found on and near the levee today (Castro et al., 2017. Plan Jarillón’s surveys found an unexpectedly complex environment which mixes publicly and privately owned land, urban and rural uses including residences and commercial activity ranging from agriculture and recycling to small-scale manufacturing.

Plan Jarillón initially relied on existing social housing to resettle families, namely the Llano Verde and Potrero Grande projects which were originally constructed through national housing programs (Calderon 2020). When this housing reached capacity, the city offered temporary rental assistance while it worked to fast-track the construction of new social housing projects. However, as the city struggled to build new housing, residents found themselves renting for extended and undefined periods of time. Under pressure to complete the relocations, the project created a new mode of compensation, housing vouchers, which residents could use to find their own permanent housing solution in the open market. This shift in strategy generated a great deal of uncertainty for residents as it pushed them into the open market which historically has excluded them through a process of racial stigmatization and segregation (Calderon 2020; Castillo-Valencia and Vivas Pacheco, 2023; Mayorga et al., 2013).

Plan Jarillón’s project leaders justified forced evictions on the basis that residents in these informal settlements constitute a risk to the rest of the city. That is, these settlements contribute to the deterioration of the levee system and stand in the way of infrastructure upgrades. A project manager at Fondo Adaptación, argued, “But the whole levee is populated with invasions. So, what I have are people who live there who are not necessarily at risk but by occupying the levee are putting at risk all of the other people who live behind the levee…So, this is a forced resettlement necessitated by the need to protect the city of Cali.” A consultant for the city, supported this position, stating that project leaders must make clear to the public what is at stake, “you are posing a danger to the rest of the city. We have to tell people we understand this may affect you adversely but you are also being compensated, and think for a second, your actions are putting a million residents at risk because you live in a critical area that shapes risk in the city, you are increasing risk in the city.”

Racial segregation and climate risk in Cali

Implicated in Plan Jarillón’s forced relocations is the city’s history of racial exclusion in the housing market. Identified in the Colombian census as Afro-Colombians, black residents officially make up 30 percent of the city’s two and a half million residents. Given the size of their population in Cali, and in the surrounding region, they define the cultural identity of the city. Bringing with them the Pacific Coast region’s unique Afro-Colombian culture, colloquially known as “El Pacifico,” these new residents have fundamentally shaped the city’s social and cultural terrain forming what they call the “Pacifico Urbano.” They are popularly associated with “black neighborhoods” such as those found in the Aguablanca District, a part of the city characterized by the presence of large informal settlements (Calderon, 2020; Castillo-Valencia and Vivas Pacheco, 2023). These neighborhoods exist in a complex relationship with the rest of the city as they are simultaneously stigmatized and othered as poor and violent and celebrated for their local traditions in music and dance. Yet, despite their central presence in the city’s social imaginary, officially, the segregation of black residents in Cali has been largely invisible in formal city plans.

A lawyer and community organizer in Playa Renaciente explained, “Cali has the largest population of self-recognized Afro-Colombians and even then, there is no public policy that exists to protect and support these communities. There is no political will, there is systemic discrimination, there is no will to protect or create the conditions for a dignified life for black communities in the city.”

Analysis of residential patterns in Cali reveals that black communities are overrepresented in the city’s floodplains. Moreover, it shows that these communities, as illustrated in Map 2.B., are disproportionately located in areas with the highest risks of landslides and chronic flooding. The city’s assessment of social vulnerability factors indicates that these risks are closely linked with informal development, characterized by inadequate housing conditions, lack of basic services and sanitation, and low-income status. This elevated risk is exacerbated by the informal nature of development in these areas (Calderon, 2020; Castillo-Valencia and Vivas Pacheco, 2023). For instance, Figure 2(C) demonstrates that the most socially vulnerable residents are found in the floodplains of the city’s eastern periphery, where large informal settlements are concentrated. In fact, according to local residents, the Aguablanca District traces its name to the periodic flooding it has experienced throughout its history. Consequently, in Cali, black residents are overrepresented in neighborhoods facing the greatest risks of flooding and the poorest quality housing.Figure 2.The spatial distribution of climate risk and social vulnerability in Cali. (A) Simulated flood risk; (B) population density of black residents; (C) population density of socially vulnerable households. Sources: IDESC, City of Santiago De Cali (2020).

Pointing to the racial discrimination black residents experienced in Project Plan Jarillón’s relocations, the leader from Playa referenced the Potrero Grande housing project, which in English roughly translates to the Grand Corral. He noted, “What happened with Potrero, I mean think of the name, the name says it, what they think of us, but we are not animals, we can’t be treated like animals.” Others argued that the city’s housing voucher alternative was ineffective because, as the leader from Brisas explained, “An advantage we have in Cali is that Cali has been the main receiver of displaced people from Guapi, Choco, El Pacifico, so being black here is normal. But there is some discrimination in the rental market, because they think because we are black, we have big families. And with a small budget we can only pay for small apartments.” She concluded, by asking families to accept small apartments in exchange for their self-built homes on the levee, the relocations constituted a form of racial dispossession.

Insurgent planning: Resistance to Plan Jarillón’s Resettlements

Insurgent planning in this study refers specifically to the community organizing and discursive strategies used by black communities to resist the city’s resettlement plans, engage public institutions and shape policies. This organizing, rooted in Afro-Colombian culture and traditions of resistance, consisted of forming ‘ancestral’ community councils and their organizing arms known as ‘cimarron guards.’ The formation of these councils enabled communities on the levee to assert territorial sovereignty, coordinate across impacted areas, and demand greater participation in the city’s decision-making process.

Codified in the 1991 Colombian constitution, Law 70 of 1993 provides the legal basis for ancestral community councils and enables them to act as political representatives for ethnic minorities. Specifically, it grants them the legal right to claim sovereignty and collective rights over historically inhabited land. As such it is meant to protect their traditional governance structures, and cultural and economic practices such as fishing, sand mining and agriculture. Importantly, ancestral lands are designated rural lands beyond the city’s jurisdiction. Therefore, ancestral communities can acquire legal status only by registering with Colombia’s Ministry of the Interior.7

For the communities in this study, gaining legal recognition, however, was complicated by informal development, which obscures both property and municipal boundaries, and their location in high-risk zones where residential development is prohibited by municipal law. Consequently, while the city viewed relocations as a restitution of public property and part of its risk mitigation strategy, communities experienced them as racial exclusion and undermining their Afro-Colombian traditions (Figure 3).Figure 3.Community councils in Brisas del Cauca and Playa Renaciente, Cali. Sources: Sarmiento (2020).

Playa Renaciente was the only community to successfully gain legal recognition as an ancestral community council. They won this recognition in 2015 through a legal and political strategy consisting of lawsuits and the formation of political alliances with city councilmembers. Through this strategy, Playa stalled the city’s relocation plans and established the community’s location in the Corregimiento de Navarro, a provincial subdivision outside of the city’s municipal boundaries and jurisdiction. The leaders of Playa Renaciente can trace their history 200 years back to this site. On a visit to Playa, a community leader introduced himself, “I’m the legal community representative for the ancestral community council of the black community Playa Renaciente.” He explained, “Before this was a commercial port, everything that came to Cali came through here. The first slaves which came to Cali were transported through here, on steamboats from Cartagena in the 1830s” In turn, city leaders recognized this historical connection and legal right but argued the risk of flooding took precedence, “But what about the flooding? That the others [not you] are at risk! So there we are listening to all that story and they say we are equal to everyone else on the Jarillón but we are more equal than the rest [he laughed] … you need to give us a church, a school, you have to take us to a river where there is a site like the one we live in. And it is a small community, a community of 210 families, the value of what they are asking is almost the value of what we are spending on the entire Jarillón to relocate families.”

La Palma pursued a similar legal strategy and was the first community to create a cimarron guard and to organize public protests of Plan Jarillón. Although it was unsuccessful in forming a legally recognized ancestral community council, since according to the city’s territorial plan, a portion of La Palma is located within municipal boundaries, the city did recognize the community’s traditional practices and agriculture-based livelihoods. Consequently, La Palma only experienced partial relocations with most of the community’s territorial boundaries left intact. A leader from La Palma explained, “We have been marked by Plan Jarillón …. So, we are just waiting. But they have not been able to make us, the council sign documents, because Law 70 and the OIT accords protect us as black communities, we are Raizales del Pacifico [natives from the Pacific], we are displaced families, displaced by the armed conflict. We are not invaders.”

Brisas del Cauca was recognized by Plan Jarillón, and communities across the levee, as the most active and vocal resistance leaders. They coordinated the network of cimarron guards across the levee and led mass public protests. In the summer of 2019, they occupied the public plaza in front of city hall for 3 months. In a symbolic protest against displacement, residents brought their belongings, including home furniture and beds, that had been taken out of their homes when the city took possession of their property. Through these actions they brought the public’s attention to the violence experienced by residents as a result of the city’s forced evictions. Ultimately, however, Brisas del Cauca, was the least successful community in preventing forced evictions. Since they refused to participate in the city’s relocation process, the city argued they had forfeited their claim to compensation and could be forcefully evicted. Ultimately, Brisas was almost entirely demolished and displaced from the levee.

The cimarron guards which typically consisted of approximately 20 to 25 residents were organized to resist city interventions in a community’s territory. In practice they functioned as symbols of resistance and a means for showing solidarity between communities. When one community was threatened with evictions, cimarron guards from across the levee were mobilized to collectively resist. The leader from Brisas explained: “We studied the history of the black cimarons, the black communities who did not want to be enslaved, they would escape and form their own territories they called “palenques.” White people could not go to “palenques” because they were independent. That’s where the idea of the guards comes from. The guard represents creating an autonomous authority. I am a guardian of my territory. No agency from the state can enter the territory without permission from the guard.”

Through the combination of protest and lawsuits residents were able to bring the project to a stop for almost half a year. During this period Plan Jarillón was audited by Colombia’s Comptroller’s office. This audit held public hearings on the project’s relocations and confirmed many of the complaints brought by residents including the misallocation of resources and errors in the compensation process.

Responding to the city’s reluctance to recognize their community councils, the community leader in Brisas argued the city selectively recognized their black identity as a matter of convenience. She explained, “We teach the children how to play the marimba, El Culun, El Wasa - the music of the Pacific - so that we don’t lose that, in fact our children will participate in the Petronio Festival. So, for some things [according to the city] we are black and for others we are not, to form a council we are not black but to go to those festivals we are black.”8

Community resistance to the project culminated with a change in Plan Jarillón’s leadership and a change in its engagement strategy. The new city administration, which had formed an alliance with the community councils during their electoral campaign, appointed a new director for Plan Jarillón. Signaling a shift in strategy this new director stopped all forced evictions and publicly recognized Playa Renaciente’s status as an ancestral black community by attending a memorial service for the community’s late and long-time leader.

Constructing counter-narratives: Living with water in the Pacific Coast region

New discourses, namely the creation of counter-narratives which assert a cultural and economic practice of living near water, formed a critical part of insurgent planning on the levee. Community councils claimed an economic dependence on river-based livelihoods, a proficiency in flood risk management and environmental stewardship of the river ecosystem derived from their traditions and historical affinity to water in Colombia’s Pacific Coast region. Through these narratives, they sought to remove the negative stigma associated with informal settlements on the levee and to gain control over the terms for their relocation. They argued the city’s resettlement plan had to account for the communities’ cultural and economic dependence on water.

The leader of Playa added that traditionally their livelihood has depended on the river. Therefore, they have created cultural practices which preserve this collective memory and identity. He explained, “The community depends on traditional practices, gathering construction materials such as sand and bamboo. We recognize this on the 15th of August when we organize a “balsada” on the river paying homage to the Virgin of Asuncion, a lot of people from across the city come to see this.” The Balsada, the ceremonial launching of a raft on the river, is a tradition founded in 1952. It marks a catastrophic flood event in which the river breached its banks disrupting sand mining activities and sending the community into an economic crisis. According to community lore, a woman from the community constructed a raft and set out on the river to pray to the Virgin asking for the water levels to return to normal. Since then, the tradition has been kept alive to maintain a balance between the river and the community (Figure 4).

The community councils also created new discursive symbols that emphasize their territorial identity. For example, each council designed its own flag which they attached to the staff carried by community guards. The leader from Brisas described their flag, “black is because of our color, red represents our history of resistance and the blood spilled in the struggle to liberate ourselves from slavery, and the blue is the seas and rivers because we black people always look to be close to the river.” The leader from Las Palmas explained the significance behind their staff, “The staff is the symbol of our race, when the Spanish had black people as slaves, this baston represents their fight to claim and protect their territory. For the cloth, black represents our race, red the blood we carry and the one you carry as well, and the green is nature. In addition to being black we are cultivators who protect the environment”.Figure 4.Mural at the entrance to Playa Renaciente. Source: Sarmiento (2020).

A critical component of the counter-narrative was an assertion of their cultural competency in flood risk management. Community councils argued their residents are an asset for climate adaptation because they know how to live with water and manage risk in these environments. In fact, living next to rivers and the coast has always been part of their culture and way of life. They know how to not only deal with flooding but also protect the environment on the Jarillón. The leader from Playa argued: “Why don’t they train the community so that they can manage this mega project in their territory...What I always say is if they are going to build a tourist port then why not build capacity with the community that already lives there and knows the river why bring external people...They say this is a high-risk zone, but if this is high risk then they would have to relocate all those pacific coast zones.” City representatives acknowledged these communities have learned to live with water, referring to them as ‘amphibious communities.’ A city representative explained, “It always floods here. In Juanchito these people are already adapted to flooding. They build their homes to adapt to the changing water levels. They have multi story homes. They have some furniture on the first level but primarily live on the second floor. When the river floods they move their belongings from the lower levels in their homes to higher levels. They are a black population that from their origins, they came here navigating, they are in the bamboo business. So they say we know how to live here, we are not moving.”

The leader of Brisas explained, “The people always look for the areas close to the banks of the river. We are from the Pacific. In the Pacific living close to the river is normal. It is normal for the tides to rise and fall. It is part of our culture.”

A lawyer, and manager of a local community center for black youth, who supported the community of Playa added, “But if you stop and think of what it means to be a black community in this country, they are always in high-risk areas, because they live in places where they have a close relationship with rivers, black communities know how to live with the river...What they are fighting for is their lives and livelihoods because they live from the land from the water...How does that European model of development affect ancestral communities? They want to showcase the pretty things, the folkloric things, but not protect their livelihoods...What better strategy than to have a community living there who knows how to manage the river?”

Ultimately, the aim of these counter-narratives was not to resist relocation but to exact concessions and gain control over the process. For example, they connected their cultural connection to water to the desire for decent housing. The leader from Brisas explained, “We are not saying we won’t go, just that we want to do it on our terms…In the city’s territorial plan they say they are relocating residents, but that is not true, what they are doing is a forced displacement. We are not asking for riches we are just asking for a decent relocation.”

DiscussionShaping climate adaptation in Cali

This case study reveals that through an insurgent planning practice defined by local culture and traditions of resistance, black communities in Cali have transformed Project Plan Jarillón—the city’s largest investment in climate adaptation to date. Their actions led to fundamental changes in Plan Jarillon’s housing relocation plan and governance strategies. Specifically, they resulted in the creation of a new platform for participatory planning in climate adaptation, innovations in subsidies to support resettlement alternatives to social housing, and an increased investment in community-based environmental stewardship programs.

Playa’s success in gaining legal recognition as an ancestral community council made available a participatory planning mechanism known as “consulta previa” or ‘prior consultation.’ Prior consultation requires local and regional governments to consult with community councils before making planning interventions in their territories. As a “constitutional and collective right,” it is “a process, public in character, meant to protect the social, cultural and economic integrity of ethnic minorities” in Colombia.9 Using prior consultation as a platform, Playa’s residents have engaged Plan Jarillón in a planning process which explores on-site and collective relocation schemes, flood resilience design interventions and building typologies.

Plan Jarillón also created new subsidies to support a resettlement process that was more sensitive to the particular needs of residents. It began with common subsidies designed to relocate individual households and resettle them in social housing projects. This type of housing is built in economies of scale typically consisting of small individual apartment units in large towers. It therefore represents a traumatic rupture in lifestyles for residents accustomed to living in multi-family housing with open spaces for agricultural and economic activity. In response to this, Plan Jarillón began offering housing vouchers to give residents the ability to find homes outside of social housing. It also designed new housing projects in which units were accompanied by “productive units,” or additional open space where residents can continue pre-existing agricultural and economic activities. The city, with support from Colombia’s housing ministry, is now piloting a neighborhood upgrading program which integrates these resettlement strategies in informal settlements located in the city’s western periphery and vulnerable to landslides.

Finally, drawing on the ancestral community councils’ community guardians, Plan Jarillón created an environmental stewardship program called “Guardians of the Levee” for the areas of the levee left vacant after relocations. This program currently consists of a network of six community gardens across the levee managed by former residents and new residents in nearby social housing projects. The city invested in their startup and plans to hand them over to non-profit organizations for sustained operation. The gardening spaces rely on regional Afro-Colombian agricultural practices and knowledge.

Conclusion

Cali’s Afro-Colombian communities challenged Project Plan Jarillón, one of Latin America’s largest climate adaptation projects, to deal with the city’s history of excluding and spatially segregating black residents. Without a policy framework to guide its work, the project devised a contentious relocation strategy, including the forced eviction of the communities which occupy the levee. Yet, these communities responded by successfully organizing an insurgent planning practice which reframes public debate from one of the financial risk flooding poses to the city to one of cultural recognition, access to decent housing and racial justice for the city’s black communities. The consequent innovation in housing strategies beyond the typical subsidies for uniform, single-family apartment units, is especially significant for these communities. It represents an attempt to preserve the livelihood, cultural practices and knowledge which inform the unique social-environmental relationship they have with water ecosystems in the Colombian Pacific Coast region. Moreover, the application of prior consultation to the Plan Jarillón planning process is a potentially transformative practice as it creates new entry points for residents who desire to advance and participate in a collective vision for climate adaptation.

This insurgent planning has potentially broad and long-term implications for climate policy in Cali and across Colombia. Locally, the city’s housing department is considering how it might codify in municipal policy the housing subsidy and compensation strategy used in Project Plan Jarillón. City agencies, such as the disaster risk management agency, are also integrating the lessons learned through the project and building a stronger institutional capacity for flood risk management and governance practices. On the national scale, Fondo Adaptación is drawing from its macro project experiences across the country, including Project Plan Jarillón, to inform national climate policy specifically as it relates to housing and governance. The Petro administration which views climate justice as integral to Colombia’s post-conflict process also strongly supports these policy efforts.

Still, despite these gains, serious challenges remain for Cali’s ability to scale and sustain new forms of climate adaptation planning. Structurally racism is still deeply embedded in the city’s housing market. This is evident in the racial segregation found across the city. Consequently, black residents continue to be over represented in the city’s floodplains with the highest risk levels. The city also continues to experience an influx of new arrivals who contribute to cycles of land “invasions” in which the city recovers land from risk areas only for it to be repopulated by self-built housing. Last, these gains are contingent on relatively new and small city agencies to develop the institutional capacity to effectively integrate them into local housing and disaster risk management practice.

Thus, the Santiago de Cali case provides evidence that reframing climate urbanism in terms of the politics of place brings into view the highly contested social and cultural terrains in which urban climate adaptation projects take place. Specifically, it enables a better understanding of how excluded communities might transform climate adaptation in cities through insurgent planning, acts of resistance and calls for a reparative approach to spatial inequality. Such a reframing points to new lines of investigation including a deeper examination of the role housing policy can play in supporting urban adaptations to climate change. That is, adaptation necessarily involves a closer look at access to quality housing and infrastructure in cities, and how it conditions residential mobility patterns with respect to climate risk. Ultimately it forces recognition that in cities, where exclusionary policies and planning practices have restricted access and fixed residents of color in the highest risk areas, contention over housing and displacement will increasingly define climate justice.

urn:contentItem:6GH3-7NV3-RRV8-32PW-00000-00All neighbourhoods in Doncaster at risk of dangerous heatwaves2025-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexisHUMAN INTERESTAll neighbourhoods in Doncaster at risk of dangerous heatwavesStephanie Batemanstephanie.bateman@nationalworld.com

All neighbourhoods in Doncaster are at risk of dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research shows all 39 neighbourhoods in Doncaster were considered "high heat" areas, meaning they experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022 and are likely to be exposed to future heatwaves.

Of these areas, 17 neighbourhoods had an enhanced risk of health impacts from heatwaves due to other factors such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715 high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all – but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms – as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

It included 78 care homes, 10 hospitals, and 55 nurseries in Doncaster.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government’s climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activist Doug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies – and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government’s lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."

urn:contentItem:6GH3-7NV3-RRV8-3358-00000-00All neighbourhoods in Luton at risk of dangerous heatwaves2025-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexisWEATHERAll neighbourhoods in Luton at risk of dangerous heatwavesSonja Tutty, Data Reporter

All neighbourhoods in Luton are at risk of dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research shows all 22 neighbourhoods in Luton were considered "high heat" areas, meaning they experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022 and are likely to be exposed to future heatwaves.

Of these areas, 15 neighbourhoods had an enhanced risk of health impacts from heatwaves due to other factors such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715 high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all – but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms – as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

It included 35 care homes, seven hospitals, and 51 nurseries in Luton.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government’s climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activist Doug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies – and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government’s lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."

urn:contentItem:6GGX-W093-S46X-V4GB-00000-00One neighbourhood in Cornwall at risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across England2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexisWEATHER NEWS & UK NEWSOne neighbourhood in Cornwall at risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across EnglandSonja Tutty

One neighbourhood in Cornwall is at risk of dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research shows Bude and Stratton in Cornwall was considered a "high heat" area, meaning it experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022 and is likely to be exposed to future heatwaves.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts due to a combination of factors, such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all - but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms - as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

It included four care homes, two hospitals, and four nurseries in Cornwall.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government's climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activistDoug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies - and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government's lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."

urn:contentItem:6GGX-W093-S46X-V4H2-00000-00All neighbourhoods in West Devon at low risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across England2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexisWEATHER NEWS & UK NEWSAll neighbourhoods in West Devon at low risk of dangerous heatwaves - as map reveals heatwave hotspots across EnglandSonja Tutty

All neighbourhoods in West Devon are at a lower risk of future dangerous heatwaves, new research suggests.

Environmental charity Friends of the Earth analysed 2022 heatwave data, when temperatures rose above 40C, alongside data on the number of older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients to reveal which areas across England are at risk from future heatwaves.

As hotter weather hits the UK this week, the charity called on the Government to take "urgent action to protect those most under threat".

The research found no neighbourhoods in West Devon are considered "high heat" areas, meaning none of them experienced the hottest temperatures in 2022.

Across the country, the charity identified 4,715high heat neighbourhoods. It included 1,920 at an enhanced risk of health impacts due to a combination of factors, such as a lack of green space, an older population, and low income.

Friends of the Earth campaigner, Denis Fernando, said: "Heatwaves are becoming more frequent and more extreme as climate change gathers pace.

"The UK has been hit by thousands of heat-related deaths over recent years, and this could rise to over 10,000 a year by 2050, according to government advisors.

"Extreme heat affects us all - but some communities and people are affected harder than others, including older people, young children, people with health issues and hospital patients."

He added: "The Government must urgently overhaul its weak climate adaptation plans to protect communities, especially those most at risk, from increasingly severe weather events such as heatwaves, floods and storms - as well as doing more to cut the emissions that are fuelling the crisis."

The analysis also found 9,589 care or nursing homes, 1,012 hospitals and 10,064 nurseries are in high heat neighbourhoods.

In July, Friends of the Earth and two people impacted by the climate crisis filed an official complaint with the European Court of Human Rights over the UK Government's climate adaptation programme.

The group said the Government's plans and policies for protecting communities from the impacts of climate change are "inadequate".

One of the co-claimants is disability rights activistDoug Paulley, a care home resident in West Yorkshire, who has health conditions which are exacerbated by hot temperatures.

Mr Paulley said: "Time and again, disabled people are treated as an expendable afterthought in emergencies - and climate change is one of the biggest.

"The Government's lack of effective consideration for us in its climate action plan is completely unacceptable."

A Government spokesperson said: "Alongside becoming a clean energy superpower, the Government is taking robust action to adapt to a changing climate.

"The National Adaptation Programme includes steps to make local communities become more resilient to overheating, a Local Advisory Climate Service to give authorities support and we're putting £30 billion into improving hospital buildings.

"We urge people to take extra care in the hot weather with building regulations in place to reduce the risk of new homes overheating and housing tenants can speak to their council if excess heat means that their property is in a dangerous condition."

urn:contentItem:6GCN-0KN3-RXF9-8518-00000-00-Bam - AM and Amvest acquire former Draka site in Amsterdam North2025-07-30T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexis-Bam - AM and Amvest acquire former Draka site in Amsterdam North

Area developers AM (a subsidiary of Royal BAM Group) and Amvest have acquired the former Draka site in Amsterdam North from Prysmian, Hines and Provast.

The 50,000 m-2 site provides space for approximately 150,000 m-2 of gross floor area to be developed.



Over the coming years, a vibrant new urban district will be created, offering plenty of space to live, work, and relax. The acquisition of the Draka site ranks among the largest development land purchases in the Netherlands in recent years. 1,600 homes - two-thirds affordable

The ambitious plans include the construction of around 1,600 new homes on the five-hectare site, two-thirds of which will be offered at below-market rates. Additionally, some 30,000 m-2 is earmarked for light industry, office space, and hospitality. The area is situated directly on the IJ, with views over Java Island. Water and nature will play a central role in the design, enhancing both quality of life and climate adaptation.

Future-proof and nature-inclusive

AM and Amvest aim to create a future-proof, inclusive neighbourhood that complements the dynamics of the wider Hamerkwartier. The design will emphasise climate adaptation, nature-inclusive building and a balanced mix of residential, work and communal spaces.

Quality and affordability

Ronald Huikeshoven, Chairman of AM's board, said: 'With the purchase of this area we are once again investing in the future of Amsterdam and contributing to the urgent housing challenge. On this beautifully located site, we want to create a sustainable, high-quality residential environment. We are committed to quality, affordability and a careful integration into the character of the area. Together with our partners, we intend to develop a new neighbourhood here that will be of real value to current and future generations.'

Implementation timeline

Demolition is expected to commence at the end of this year, followed by environmental remediation. The development will be carried out in phases, with construction due to begin in 2027 once the zoning plan is approved. The site has been fenced off for over a decade; during redevelopment, AM and Amvest plan to reopen it to the public, even while construction is underway.

urn:contentItem:6GF7-5K03-S5JW-24CT-00000-00Cairngorms National Park Authority's climate change package for land managers2025-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT NEWS & CLIMATE CHANGE NEWSCairngorms National Park Authority's climate change package for land managerstom.ramage@hnmedia.co.uk (Tom Ramage)

Farmers, land managers and businesses will share a £270,000 pay-out from the Cairngorms National Park to help them adapt to the changing climate.

The recipients of the park's 2025 Climate Adaptation Fund were announced yesterday (Wednesday). The awards will go towards practical, on-the-ground solutions to help tackle and mitigate the effects of climate change - including responding to wildfires.

"This year's fund attracted over 60 expressions of interest and more than 30 full applications," a CNPA spokesperson confirmed. "The total value of proposed projects exceeded £1 million, highlighting the desire from farmers, land managers, business and community groups to contribute to climate action across the national park."

The 12 successful projects include: a remote-controlled track flail mower to reduce the height of brush, helping reduce wildfire risk in Kingussie; equipment and collaboration to enhance wildfire resilience across Badenoch and Strathspey and further afield at Alvie and Dalraddy Estates; firefighting equipment, personal protection equipment and fire prevention equipment including hand cutting tools for building wildfire resilience at Dalnacardoch.

Also funded will be a low ground pressure slurry tank to use the waste product from the whisky industry as fertiliser in Grantown, and installation of solar panels and battery storage solution at Scrumpy's coffee shop in the Strathspey capital.

Money will go towards the planting of riparian trees along the upper River Spey by the Spey Riparian Collaboration.

Mairi Gougeon, rural affairs secretary, said: "This fund is the latest example of the vital, hands-on role our national parks play in helping local communities meet environmental and climate-related challenges head on. It empowers farmers, land managers and businesses to take meaningful steps to mitigate the impacts of climate change. In the wake of the recent wildfires, it couldn't be timelier to focus on practical equipment to help fight fires on our precious landscape. These projects will deliver swift and practical benefits to those striving to safeguard their livelihoods and support restoration efforts in the Cairngorms National Park."

The Climate Adaptation Fund first launched in 2024 to support capital works and investments in response to the environmental challenges we're facing in the wake of climate change. Together with this year's fund, £640,000 has now been awarded to 30 recipients in the National Park. The fund aligns with the Cairngorms National Park Partnership Plan 2022-2027. Projects needed to demonstrate that they fit with the Plan's priorities and contribute to the delivery of the Scottish Government's National Climate Change Adaptation Programme.

Sandy Bremner, Convener of the Cairngorms National Park Authority, said: "This funding underlines the National Park's absolute commitment to support people dealing with the practical challenges of a changing climate. It will help to tackle threats to lives, livelihoods and our natural heritage. The focus on wildfires builds on our wider initiatives, from the UK's first integrated wildfire management plan to the widely supported byelaw on recreational fires, now awaiting Scottish Government approval."

In submitting projects for the fund, applicants were encouraged to deliver economic benefits through local employment and enterprise. In addition, applicants were asked to consider nature-based solutions, with the Park Authority prioritising projects that promote habitat and species recovery.

Grant Moir, the park authority's CEO, said: "The scale of the ambition among farmers, land managers and businesses to act to mitigate the effects of climate change is clear. These 12 projects will have a real and lasting impact and will support efforts to adapt to the changing climate - particularly devastating wildfires experienced in and close to the National Park in recent weeks - while supporting biodiversity enhancement, local jobs and sustainable land use practices."

Jamie Williamson, Laird at Alvie and Dalraddy Estates, said: "The support we received from last year's Climate Adaptation Fund went towards the purchase of fire suppression equipment. This included a trailer-mounted fire fogging unit and a slurry tanker adapted for tackling wildfires with a rain gun to extinguish fires at a distance and with the ability to supply water to replenish fire fogging units with limited water carrying capacity. Our estate team supported the efforts of the fire service and other local estates in tackling the recent wildfires, using this equipment.

"We are pleased to have received further support from this year's fund which will go towards purchasing an all-terrain vehicle equipped with a fire fogging unit, a backpack blower, radios and firefighting PPE including overalls, gloves and masks. This equipment could also be used across Badenoch and Strathspey and further afield if needed."

FIRE-FIGHTERS: Colin McClean, head of land management at the CNPA (left), and Jamie Williamson, laird at Alvie and Dalraddy Estates, with a slurry tanker adapted for fighting wildfires which was funded in the 2024 round.

urn:contentItem:6FJW-RFK3-RTNT-M319-00000-00'At risk' areas revealed in Colchester's climate adaptation report2025-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:13ZLexisNexis'At risk' areas revealed in Colchester's climate adaptation reportS\xC3amus O'Hanlon

A MAJOR climate change report has been published by Colchester council, with heatwaves and flooding predicted to become more frequent in years to come.

City leaders declared a climate emergency back in 2019 and committed to becoming carbon neutral as an organisation by 2030.

The council commissioned a report which includes climatic projections for Colchester and reflects on how the region has been affected in recent years.

The report said in the years until 2030, Colchester could experience temperature rises of 1 C annually compared to 1990 levels.

Alternative models show temperatures could increase by up to five degrees in summer.

The potential for heatwaves is likely to increase.

Data shows there are five days on average above 25 C per summer month between 1991 to 2019.

This is predicted to increase to 19 days on average in the years from 2041 to 2070.

Prediction - Area of North Essex that are projected to be under the annual flood level by 2050 (Image: Colchester Council)

According to the UK Climate Risk Indicator Explorer, Essex is the second-most at risk county for wildfires in the UK.

Essex is also still classed as a severely water stressed area and the average water use in the county is 155 to 160 litres per person per day - far above the UK average of 144 litres.

The report also said Climate Central predicts many areas of Colchester will be below the annual flood level - areas which statistically flood every year on average.

This includes much of Mersea Island, parts of Wivenhoe and Rowhedge, and urban areas along the River Colne due to rises in sea levels.

The report said the overall time for which the Strood will be impassable to vehicles will likely increase which will impact access to Mersea island.

A spokesman for Colchester Council said: -Climate change is already impacting our city - through extreme heat, flooding, and drought - and these risks are only set to grow.

-That-s why Colchester joined a national Defra-led pilot to assess how local authorities can better adapt services and planning in response.

"This report marks the beginning of a more coordinated, long-term approach to adapting Colchester for the future.-

Despite the concerns, Anglian Water has said it does not expect to enforce a hosepipe ban this summer.

A spokesman said: -We know the East of England is set to see wetter winters and drier summers as climate change progresses, and that Colchester will be especially hard hit.

-That-s why we-re working hard to make sure our water and sewerage infrastructure in the area is ready to adapt to climate change, so we can keep our customers- taps flowing and toilets flushing for years to come, as Essex-s population is set to grow at 10 per cent by 2043.-

The spokesman said this year-s reservoir levels were -very good- meaning they do not expect any temporary usage bans or hosepipe bans this summer.

Anglian Water will also be building a 100million reuse site called the Colchester advanced water recycling which will begin construction next year with a demonstration centre.

New reservoirs and pipelines to move water from the wetter parts of our region to the drier areas, including Essex, will also be made,

More smart meters will also be installed to reduce water usage.

The spokesman also said there was the additional risk of flooding and Anglian Water will be upgrading their storm storage at several of their water recycling centres in Essex as well as install -new state-of-the-art- sewer monitors on their network.

Castle ward councillor Mark Goacher said it is important for future generations that climate change is addressed.

Concerned - Mark Goacher said southeast England was at particular risk of water scarcity due to the rising population and lack of adequate infrastructure to support it (Image: Steve Brading) He said: -First of all, it is very important for all councils to do these reports as this will seriously affect people-s lives for a long period of time - particularly people who live on coastal areas with the risk of flooding, as well as weather changes and risk of flooding.

-I am very aware there is a feeling that, as this is such a big issue, the approach should be that we bury our heads in the sand - in the general public there is that attitude and we need to do work like this to show the potential risk.-

Mr Goacher said that the report was important -irrespective- of whether you believe climate change is man-made or natural as it is a -risk-assessment- for the region.

He added water scarcity impacts the southeast of England harder because infrastructure has not grown in line with the population increase.

He said: -The challenge with the climate change mitigation movement is to make sure it does not mean 'impoverishing the average person'.

-We need to get the funding from those who have the broadest shoulders.-
